history.content:
1) Each vertex contains one literal. 

2) There are 2n vertices - one per literal, as you list.

3) I don't know what meta-vertices are - do you mean connected components? The example from lecture is a DAG, so its vertices are also its connected components, but this is not generally true - the CNF formula doesn't have to form a DAG. For example: $$(x_1 \vee x_3) \wedge (\bar{x_3} \vee x_2) \wedge (\bar{x_1} \vee \bar{x_2}) \wedge (\bar{x_1} \vee x_3) $$.

4) Each vertex must have a complement vertex, this is how you end up with 2n vertices. Each sink SCC $$S$$ must have a source SCC $$\bar{S}$$ such that $$S=T$$ implies $$\bar{S}=F$$.

4) Each vertex must have a complement vertex, this is how you end up with 2n vertices. Each sink SCC $$S$$ must have a source SCC $$\bar{S}$$ such that $$S=T$$ implies $$\bar{S}=F$$.

2) There are 2n vertices - one per literal, as you list.

3) I don't know what meta-vertices are - do you mean connected components? The example from lecture is a DAG, so its vertices are also its connected components, but this is not generally true - the CNF formula doesn't have to form a DAG.

1) Each vertex contains one literal. 

2) There are 2n vertices - one per literal as you list.

3) I don't know what meta-vertices are - do you mean connected components? The example from lecture is a DAG, so its vertices are also its connected components, but this is not generally true - the CNF formula doesn't have to form a DAG.

4) Each vertex must have a compliment vertex, this is how you end up with 2n vertices. Each sink SCC $$S$$ must have a source SCC $$\bar{S}$$ such that $$S=T$$ implies $$\bar{S}=F$$.

Hi All,

So I see that in the 2-SAT algorithm there are vertices; in the lecture, it seems each vertex has a few literals in it. My questions:

  1. What determines the literals contained in a vertex? Is there a limit on how many can be in one vertex?
  2. Is the 'universe' of vertices a Cartesian combination of the literals ($$x_1$$, $$\bar{x_1}$$.... $$x_n$$, $$\bar{x_n}$$)? OR, are these actually meta-vertices which are the result of running a SCC and then lumping the original, single literal vertices into large meta-vertices?
  3. Are these vertices (the ones in the lecture) meta-vertices or are they just regular vertices?
  4. MUST there be a compliment vertex (meta-vertex?) S`, which equals !S?

I dont know why SATs are kicking my behind, its like college entrance exams all over again!

Thanks,

Brent
history.subject: Another Question About 2-SAT And Vertices
